{{for|the American serial killer with a similar sounding name|Gerald Stano}} {{Infobox serial killer |name = Cary Stayner |image = Stayner - mugshot.jpg |caption = |birth_name = Cary Anthony Stayner |alias = The Yosemite (Park) Killer |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1961|08|13}} |birth_place = [[Merced, California]] |victims = 4 |country = United States |states = [[California]] |beginyear = February 1999 |endyear = July 1999 |apprehended = 1999 |conviction = [[First degree murder]], 4 counts |sentence = Death }}
'''Cary Anthony Stayner''' (born August 13, 1961) is an American [[serial killer]]. Stayner's early life was marked by the abduction of his younger brother, [[Steven Stayner|Steven]] by [[sex offender]] [[Kenneth Parnell]].
He was convicted of the murders of four women between February and July 1999: Carole Sund, her teenage daughter Juli Sund and their teenage traveling companion Silvina Pelosso, and [[NatureBridge|Yosemite Institute]] naturalist Joie Ruth Armstrong. The murders occurred in [[Mariposa County, California]], near [[Yosemite National Park]]. Cary Stayner was sentenced to death for the four murders, and as of September 2018 remains on death row at [[San Quentin|San Quentin Penitentiary]] in California.<ref name=T75166>{{cite web |title=Stayner, Cary Anthony |website=Inmate Locator |url=https://inmatelocator.cdcr.ca.gov/Details.aspx?ID=T75166 |publisher=California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation |accessdate=June 1, 2018}}</ref>
==Early life== <!--The Radford citation is not an acceptable encyclopedic citation for a BLP article. Instead of using student notes from a university forensic psych course, go to the references listed in that student work, and verify the content, listing the original, verifiable, sound historical source (rather than the student coursework). Le Prof.-->
Stayner was born and raised Mormon in [[Merced, California]]. His younger brother, [[Steven Stayner|Steven]], was kidnapped by [[Child molestation|child molester]] [[Kenneth Parnell]] in 1972, when Cary was 11, and held captive for more than seven years before escaping and being reunited with his family.<ref name=spokesmen>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=19890918&id=bVxWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CvADAAAAIBAJ&pg=3385,5272950&hl=en|title=Crash ends life scarred by childhood abduction|work=[[The Spokesman-Review]]|publisher=[[Cowles Company]]|location=Spokane, Washington|agency=[[Associated Press]]|pages=A1-A2|date=September 18, 1989|accessdate=June 12, 2015}}</ref> Cary Stayner later said that he felt neglected while his parents grieved over the loss of Steven.<ref name="bg">{{cite news|first1=Susan|last1=Sward|first2=Stacy|last2=Finz|first3=Meredith|last3=May|first4=Torri|last4=Minton|url=https://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Overshadowed-All-His-Life-Low-key-Cary-Stayner-2915936.php|title=Overshadowed All His Life|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]]|location=San Francisco, California|date=July 30, 1999|accessdate=June 15, 2015}}</ref>
When Steven escaped from Parnell and returned home in 1980, he received massive [[Mass media|media]] attention; a [[True crime (genre)|true crime]] book and [[TV movie]], both titled ''[[I Know My First Name is Steven]]'', were made about the ordeal. Steven died in a motorcycle accident in 1989. The following year Stayner's uncle Jesse, with whom he was living at the time, was murdered; Stayner later claimed that his uncle molested him when he was 11.<ref name="finz">{{cite news|first=Stacy|last=Finz|title=The case of a lifetime|url=https://www.sfgate.com/news/article/The-case-of-a-lifetime-For-Cary-Stayner-there-2710937.php|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]]|location=San Francisco, California|date=December 15, 2002|accessdate=June 12, 2015}}</ref>
Stayner is reported to have attempted suicide in 1991,<ref>{{cite web|first=Orrin|last=Gray|url=https://the-line-up.com/yosemite-killer|title=The Yosemite Killer: Cary Stayner's Twisted Mind|website=[[The Lineup (TV program)|The Lineup]]|date=11 September 2017|accessdate=28 June 2018}}</ref> and was arrested in 1997 for possession of marijuana<ref name="bg" /> and [[methamphetamine]],<ref>{{cite news|first1=Eric|last1=Bailey|first2=Mark|last2=Arax|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1999/jul/26/news/mn-59682|title=Man Is Suspect in Both Yosemite Murder Cases|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tronc]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=July 26, 1999|accessdate=June 28, 2018}}</ref> although these charges were eventually dropped.<ref name="bg" />
==Crimes== In 1997, Stayner was hired as a handyman at the Cedar Lodge motel in [[El Portal, California|El Portal]], just outside the Highway 140 Arch Rock entrance to Yosemite National Park.<ref name="bg" /> Between February and July 1999, he murdered two women and two teenagers: Carole Sund; her daughter, 15-year-old Juli Sund; their travel companion, 16-year-old Argentine exchange student Silvina Pelosso; and [[NatureBridge|Yosemite Institute]] employee Joie Ruth Armstrong, 26, a naturalist.<ref name="finz" /> The first two victims, Carole Sund and Silvina Pelosso, were found in the trunk of the charred remains of Carole's [[Pontiac]] rental car.<ref name="finz" /> The bodies were burned beyond recognition and were identified using dental records. A note was sent to police with a hand-drawn map indicating the location of the third victim, Juli Sund.<ref name="finz" /> The top of the note read, "We had fun with this one." Investigators went to the location depicted on the map and found the remains of Juli, whose throat had been cut.
Detectives began interviewing employees of the Cedar Lodge motel where the first three victims had been staying just before their deaths. One of those employees was Cary Stayner, but he was not considered a suspect at that point because he had no criminal history and remained calm during the police interview.<ref name=Finz>{{cite news |first=Stacy |last=Finz |date=December 14, 2002 |title=The Case of a Lifetime, Part Two |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/s/p/2002/stayner/STAYNER15PART2.DTL |work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]]|location=San Francisco, California|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080628032140/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fc%2Fs%2Fp%2F2002%2Fstayner%2FSTAYNER15PART2.DTL |archivedate=June 28, 2008 |deadurl=yes |access-date=August 13, 2016 |df= }}</ref>
When the decapitated body of the fourth victim Joie Ruth Armstrong was found, eyewitnesses said they saw a blue 1979 [[International Scout]] parked outside the cabin where Armstrong was staying. Detectives traced this vehicle to Stayner.<ref name="finz" /> This caused Stayner to become the prime suspect in the case. [[FBI]] agents John Boles and Jeff Rinek found Stayner staying at Laguna del Sol nudist resort in [[Wilton, California|Wilton]], where he was arrested. His vehicle yielded evidence linking him to Joie Armstrong. During his interrogation, Stayner confessed to the four murders as well as to sending the map for finding Juli Sund's body.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/US/9907/27/yosemite.murder.01/index.html|title=Yosemite suspect confesses to 4 killings|work=[[CNN]]|location=Atlanta, Georgia|date=July 27, 1999|accessdate=June 12, 2015}}</ref>
Stayner claimed after his arrest that he had fantasized about murdering women since he was seven years old, long before the abduction of his brother.<ref>{{cite web|first=Joshua|last=Hammer|url=http://www.outsideonline.com/1889286/yosemite-horror|title=The Yosemite Horror|website=Outside|date=November 1, 1999|accessdate=June 9, 2018}}</ref>
==Trial and conviction==
Stayner pleaded [[insanity defense|not guilty by reason of insanity]]. His lawyers claimed that the Stayner family had a history of sexual abuse and mental illness, manifesting itself not only in the murders, but also his [[obsessive-compulsive disorder]], and request to be provided with [[child pornography]] in return for his confession.<ref name="crimelibrary.com">{{cite web|first=Joseph |last=Geringer |title=Cary Stayner and the Yosemite Murders |url=http://www.crimelibrary.com/serial_killers/predators/stayner/index_1.html |work=truTV Crime Library |date=February 12, 1999 |accessdate=April 9, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513085708/http://www.crimelibrary.com/serial_killers/predators/stayner/index_1.html |archivedate=May 13, 2008 |df= }}</ref> Dr. Jose Arturo Silva testified that Stayner had mild [[autism]], obsessive-compulsive disorder, and [[paraphilia]].<ref name="SF Gate">{{cite web |first=Stacy|last=Finz|url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Stayner-called-mentally-impaired-Psychiatrist-2789309.php|title=Stayner called mentally impaired / Psychiatrist testifies for defense |work= [[San Francisco Chronicle]] |publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]]|location=San Francisco, California|date=July 30, 2002 |accessdate=July 15, 2015}}</ref> Stayner was nevertheless found sane and convicted of four counts of [[first degree murder]] by a jury on August 27, 2002.<ref>{{cite news|first=Stacy|last=Finz|url=https://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Stayner-guilty-of-1st-degree-murder-Former-2778047.php|title=Stayner guilty of 1st-degree murder / Former handyman could now face death penalty|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|publisher=[[Hearst corporation]]|location=San Francisco, California|date=August 27, 2002|accessdate=June 9, 2018}}</ref>
==Sentencing and wait for execution==
In 2002, during the [[sentence (law)|penalty phase]] of his trial, he was sentenced to death and thereafter entered housing in the Adjustment Center on death row at [[San Quentin|San Quentin Penitentiary]] in California.<ref>{{cite news|first=Stacy |last=Finz |title=Yosemite killer sentenced to death / Terrible details of Stayner case stun even the judge |url=http://www.sfgate.com/crime/article/Yosemite-killer-sentenced-to-death-Terrible-2711605.php |work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]]|location=San Francisco, California|date=December 13, 2002|accessdate=June 1, 2018}}</ref> Stayner remains on death row as of September 2018<ref name="JardineMB14">{{cite news |first=Jeff |last=Jardine |title=Waiting out the death penalty |url=https://www.modbee.com/news/local/news-columns-blogs/jeff-jardine/article3168583.html |work=[[Modesto Bee]]|publisher=[[McClatchy]]|location=Modesto, California|date=July 26, 2014 |accessdate=June 1, 2018}}</ref><ref name=T75166/> though there have been no executions in California since a 2006 court ruling finding flaws in the administration of capital punishment in the state.<ref name=JardineMB14/>
== Media portrayals == * Stayner's case was featured in an episode of ''[[American Justice]]'' produced in 2002.<ref>{{Cite episode | title = The Yosemite Killer | series = American Justice | url= https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0400168/|date=2003|network=[[A&E Television Networks]]|location=New York City}}</ref> * In 2011, the investigation and arrest of Cary Stayner were featured in an episode of ''FBI: Criminal Pursuit'', titled "Trail of Terror", airing on the [[Investigation Discovery]] channel.<ref>{{cite episode| title = Trail of Terror| date = 2011| url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1999543/fullcredits| series = FBI: Criminal Pursuit| credits = Director: David Haycox| network =[[Investigation Discovery]]| season = 1}}</ref> * In 2013, the history of Stayner's progress from student to convicted murderer was told in an episode of the U.K. television series "[[Born to Kill?]]" titled, "Yosemite Park Slayer."<ref>{{cite episode| title = Yosemite Park Slayer| date = September 3, 2013| url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3221056/?ref_=fn_al_tt_1| series = [[Born to Kill?]]| credits = Director: Neil Edwards| network =[[Sky UK]]| location=London, England|season = 1|number=4}}</ref> * The American Court TV (now [[TruTV]]) television series ''Mugshots'' released an episode on the Stayner case titled ''Cary Stayner - The Cedar Lodge Killings''.<ref>{{cite web|title=MUGSHOTS: CARY STAYNER – THE CEDAR LODGE KILLINGS|url=http://filmrise.com/mugshots-cary-stayner-the-cedar-lodge-killings/|website=FilmRise|accessdate=8 November 2017}}</ref> * In 2018, the Reelz channel aired an hour-long documentary about the murders that was titled, "Yosemite Park Killer".
== Further reading == <!--Put sources here not yet fully excerpted in support of the article's content.--> * Mara Bovsun, 2012, "Justice Story: Twisted trail of 'Yosemite murders' leads to resort handyman," ''New York Daily News'' (online), Sunday, September 30, 2012, see [http://www.nydailynews.com/news/justice-story/justice-story-twisted-trail-yosemite-murders-leads-resort-handyman-article-1.1168927], accessed 12 June 2015. [Subtitle: "Cary Stayner planned to kill his girlfriend and her daughter; instead he killed 4 other women."] * CNN, 2001 [1999], "Yosemite suspect confesses to 4 killings, ''cnn.com'' (online), July 27, 1999, see [https://edition.cnn.com/US/9907/27/yosemite.murder.01/index.html], accessed 12 June 2015. * Stacy Finz, 2002, "Yosemite killer sentenced to death," ''<small>SFGATE</small>'' (online), December 13, 2002, see [https://www.sfgate.com/default/article/Yosemite-killer-sentenced-to-death-Terrible-2711605.php], accessed 12 June 2015. [Excerpts from Stayner's confession; subtitle: "Terrible details of Stayner case stun even the judge."] * {{Citation | last = Smith | first = Carlton | title = Murder at Yosemite | publisher = St. Martins Press | series = St. Martin's True Crime Library | year = 1999 | edition = | url = | isbn = 978-0312974572}} * {{Citation | last = McDougal | first = Dennis | title = The Yosemite Murders | publisher = Ballantine Books | year = 2000 | url = | isbn = 978-0345438348}}

[[File:David de Coninck - A cat and a dog fighting over fowl, a column with draped curtain and coastal landscape beyond.jpg |thumb|''A cat and a dog fighting over fowl'']] '''David de Coninck''' or '''David de Koninck''', also known as '''Rammelaer''' (ca. 1644, [[Antwerp]] – after 1701, probably [[City of Brussels|Brussels]]) was a [[Southern Netherlands|Flemish]] painter who specialised in [[still life]]s and [[Landscape painting|landscapes]] with animals and hunting scenes. Recognised as a leading animal painter, de Coninck was able to develop an international career which caused him to work for extended periods in Paris, Rome and Vienna.
==Life== He was apprenticed to [[Pieter Boel]] in 1659. Pieter Boel was an accomplished animal painter who had been trained by [[Jan Fyt]], the leading Flemish animal painter of the mid 17th century.<ref name=dor>[https://www.dorotheum.com/en/auctions/current-auctions/kataloge/list-lots-detail/auktion/11131-old-master-paintings/lotID/86/lot/1861446-david-de-coninck.html David de Coninck (Antwerp c. 1645 – after 1701 Brussels), ''A landscape with a buzzard attacking ducks''], at Dorotheum</ref> De Coninck became a master in the Antwerp [[Guild of Saint Luke]] in 1663. [[File:Ajaccio de Coninck fruits fleurs animaux.JPG|thumb|left|''Still life of fruit and flowers with animals'']]
He moved to Paris where he worked with the prominent Flemish animal painter [[Nicasius Bernaerts]] for several years, probably until 1669.<ref name=RKD/> Nicasius Bernaerts was an influential Flemish animal painter who worked for the royal court and was a member of the [[Académie de peinture et de sculpture|Royal Academy of Painting and Sculpture]] in Paris.<ref name=con>[http://www.connaissancesdeversailles.org/t2746-nicasius-bernaerts-peintre-de-la-menagerie-de-versailles Nicasius (ou Nicaise) Bernaerts] (Anvers 1620 - Paris 1678) {{link language|fr|French}}</ref>
De Coninck subsequently travelled to [[Rome]] where he lived from 1671 to 1694. Here he became a member of the [[Bentvueghels]], an association of mainly Dutch and Flemish artists working in Rome, and took the nickname (the so-called 'bent name') 'Rammelaer' (which means 'rattle'). His name was inscribed in a niche in the [[Santa Costanza]] church in Rome where the Bentvueghels used to congregate.<ref>[http://hadrianus.it/people/david-de-coninck David de Coninck] at Hadrianus</ref>
On his return to the north he stayed for a time in [[Vienna]]. He returned to Antwerp in 1687. He moved to Brussels at some time between 1699 and 1701. The last record of de Coninck is his registration as a became a member of the Brussels Guild of Saint Luke in 1701. It is not known when or when he died.<ref name=RKD>[https://rkd.nl/en/explore/artists/17943 David de Coninck] at the [[Netherlands Institute for Art History]] {{link language|nl|Middle Dutch}}</ref>
==Work== [[File:David de Coninck - River Scene with Ducks and Geese Being Attacked by Hawks.jpg|thumb|''River Scene with Ducks and Geese Being Attacked by Hawks'']] De Coninck painted still lifes, including fruit still lifes and hunting still lifes, landscapes with hunting scenes and architectural paintings.<ref name=RKD/> De Coninck's stylistic development is unclear and it is difficult to date his paintings with any precision.<ref>[http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/david-de-coninck-dead-birds-and-game-with-gun-dogs-and-a-little-owl Dead Birds and Game with Gun Dogs and a Little Owl], probably about 1672-94, David de Coninck at the [[National Gallery]]</ref> It is possible that early in his career he painted fruit still lifes, since there is a record that in 1668 two fruit still lifes made by a 'Koninck' were exported to Vienna.<ref name=RKD/>
De Coninck's teacher Pieter Boel was a pupil of Jan Fyt, the leading Flemish animal painter of the mid 17th century. This explains the influence of Jan Fyt's style on de Coninck's work.<ref>[https://de.wikisource.org/wiki/ADB:Koninck,_David_de David de Koninck in Allgemeines Künstlerlexikon] Band XX, 1998, Seite 518 {{link language|de|German}}</ref> Some works of David de Coninck and Pieter Boel are still attributed to Fyt.<ref>[http://www.oxfordartonline.com/subscriber/article/grove/art/T030296 Arnout Balis. "Fyt , Jan."] Grove Art Online. Oxford Art Online. Oxford University Press. Web. 22 Apr. 2014</ref> As David de Coninck rarely signed his works, which are generally of a high quality and similar style they have often been confused with the works of Boel, Fyt and even Frans Snijders, the leading Flemish animal painter of the first half of the 17th century.<ref name=dor/>
His fruit still lifes of fruits and flowers painted on large canvases are complex Baroque compositions, which often include animals in an outdoor setting. Large, Italianate fruit still lifes in the [[Musée des Beaux-Arts de Nantes]] can likely also be attributed to de Coninck. An example of his fruit still lifes is the ''Still life of fruit and flowers with animals'' ([[Musée Fesch]]), which shows a still life with fruits and flowers near an outdoor fountain and a landscape in the distance. A monkey, two rabbits and a parrot enliven the painting.<ref name=RKD/> [[File:David de Coninck - Poultry and Cat.jpg|thumb|''Poultry and cat'']]
De Coninck was an accomplished painter of scenes with animals, mainly birds, in a garden or against a landscape background. He painted lively action scenes of fighting cats and dogs, packs of dogs attacking game and birds of prey or cats attacking birds or poultry.<ref name=RKD/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.erfgoedplus.be/collectie/24062A51 |title=Attacking dogs|website=erfgoedplus.be}} {{link language|nl|Middle Dutch}}</ref>
De Coninck's work influenced other artists in Italy such as [[Baldassare De Caro]], Giovanni Crivelli (named 'il Crivellino'), [[Nicola Malinconico]], [[Franz Werner von Tamm]] and [[Jacob Xavier Vermoelen]].<ref name=RKD/>
==Notes== {{reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox person |name = Fareed Zakaria |image = Fareed Zakaria, Peabody Awards (2012) (cropped).jpg |birth_name = Fareed Rafiq Zakaria |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1964|1|20}} |birth_place = [[Mumbai]], [[India]] |education = [[Yale University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[Harvard University]] ([[Master of Arts|MA]], [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]]) |awards = [[Padma Bhushan]] (2010){{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/padma-award-recipients-zakaria-parikh-say-they-are-humbled/571796/ |title=Padma award recipients Zakaria, Parikh say they are humbled |work=[[The Indian Express]] |date=2010-01-26 |accessdate=2014-03-14}} |spouse = Paula Throckmorton |children = 3 |parents = [[Rafiq Zakaria]] (father)
[[Fatima Zakaria]] (mother) |relatives = [[Asif Zakaria]] (cousin)
[[Arif Zakaria]] (cousin) |credits = ''[[Fareed Zakaria GPS]]'', host (2008–present)
''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine, contributing editor (2010–2014)
''[[Newsweek|Newsweek International]]'', editor (2000–2010)
''[[Foreign Exchange (US TV series)|Foreign Exchange]]'', host (2005–2007)
''[[Foreign Affairs]]'', former managing editor |URL = {{url|fareedzakaria.com|Official website}} }} '''Fareed Rafiq Zakaria''' ({{IPAc-en|f|ə|ˈ|r|iː|d|_|z|ə|ˈ|k|ɑr|i|ə}}; born January 20, 1964) is an [[Indians in the New York City metropolitan region|Indian-American]] journalist, political scientist and author. He is the host of [[CNN]]'s ''[[Fareed Zakaria GPS]]'' and writes a weekly column for ''[[The Washington Post]].''{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/a-new-threat-to-democracy--from-the-left/2018/09/13/7e3fbb72-b790-11e8-94eb-3bd52dfe917b_story.html?noredirect=on&utm_term=.69738ff519d3|title=The threat to democracy — from the left}} He has been a columnist for ''[[Newsweek]]'', editor of ''[[Newsweek International]]'', and an [[editor at large]] of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]].''{{cite web|url=http://www.fareedzakaria.com/home/About.html|title=Fareed Zakaria's Website|accessdate=10 May 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100825150940/http://www.fareedzakaria.com/home/About.html|archive-date=25 August 2010|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Early life== Zakaria was born in [[Mumbai]], India, to a [[Konkani Muslims|Konkani Muslim]] family.{{cite news|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2005-08-09/news/the-interpreter/|title=The Interpreter|last=Press|first=Joy|date=9 August 2005|work=The Village Voice|publisher=Village Voice, LLC|accessdate=10 May 2010}}{{Cite web|last= |first= |authorlink= |title=DNA test uncovers Fareed Zakaria's roots |publisher=[[CNN]]|date= |url= https://www.cnn.com/videos/bestoftv/2014/10/17/ac-fareed-zakaria-roots.cnn/video/playlists/roots/ |accessdate=June 1, 2018}} His father, [[Rafiq Zakaria]], was a politician associated with the [[Indian National Congress]] and an [[Islamic theologian]]. His mother, [[Fatima Zakaria]], was his father's second wife. She was for a time the editor of the ''[[The Sunday Times (India)|Sunday Times of India]]''. Zakaria attended the [[Cathedral and John Connon School]] in Mumbai. He graduated with a Bachelor of Arts from [[Yale University]] in 1986, where he was president of the [[Yale Political Union]], editor in chief of the ''[[Yale Political Monthly]],'' a member of the [[Scroll and Key]] society, and a member of the [[Party of the Right (Yale)|Party of the Right]]. He later gained a Ph.D. in [[government]] from [[Harvard University]] in 1993, where he studied under [[Samuel P. Huntington]] and [[Stanley Hoffmann]], as well as international relations theorist [[Robert Keohane]].{{Cite news|url=http://harvardmagazine.com/2012/05/harvard-graduate-school-centennial-medalists-2012|title=Harvard Graduate School Honors Daniel Aaron, Nancy Hopkins, and Others |date=23 May 2012|access-date=2012-05-29|work=Harvard Magazine}} ==Career== After directing a research project on [[Foreign relations of the United States|American foreign policy]] at [[Harvard]], Zakaria became the managing editor of ''[[Foreign Affairs]]'' in 1992, at the age of 28. Under his guidance, the magazine was redesigned and moved from a quarterly to a bimonthly schedule. He served as an [[adjunct professor]] at [[Columbia University]], where he taught a seminar on [[international relations]]. In October 2000, he was named editor of ''[[Newsweek|Newsweek International]]'', and became a weekly columnist for ''Newsweek''. In August 2010 he moved to ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' to serve as editor at-large and columnist.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/19/business/media/19mag.html|title=Newsweek Notable Moves to a Rival|last=Carr|first=David|date=18 August 2010|work=The New York Times |access-date=19 August 2010}} He writes a weekly column for ''[[The Washington Post]]'' and is a contributing editor for the Atlantic Media group, which includes ''[[The Atlantic Monthly]]''. He has published on a variety of subjects for ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', ''[[The New Yorker]]'', ''[[The New Republic]].'' For a brief period, he was a wine columnist for the web magazine ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]].''{{cite web|access-date=2008-05-20|url=http://www.slate.com/id/3519/|title=Sweet Justice|publisher=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|date=1 July 1998 |last=Zakaria |first=Fareed}}{{cite web|url=http://collegenews.org/events/2005/fareed-zakaria-to-deliver-lecture-on-world-issues-at-puget-sound-campus.html|title=Fareed Zakaria to Deliver Lecture on World Issues at Puget Sound Campus|work=College News|access-date=10 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141015222037/http://collegenews.org/events/2005/fareed-zakaria-to-deliver-lecture-on-world-issues-at-puget-sound-campus.html|archivedate=15 October 2014|df=dmy-all}} Zakaria is the author of ''From Wealth to Power: The Unusual Origins of America's World Role'' (Princeton, 1998), ''[[The Future of Freedom]]'' (Norton, 2003), ''[[The Post-American World]]'' (2008), and ''In Defense of a Liberal Education'' (Norton, 2015). He co-edited ''The American Encounter: The United States and the Making of the Modern World'' (Basic Books) with James F. Hoge Jr. His last three books have both been New York Times bestsellers and The Future of Freedom and The Post American World have both been translated into more than 25 languages. In 2011 an updated and expanded edition of ''The Post-American World'' ("Release 2.0") was published. Zakaria was a news analyst with [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s ''[[This Week (ABC TV series)|This Week with George Stephanopoulos]]'' (2002–2007) where he was a member of the Sunday morning roundtable. He hosted the weekly TV news show, ''[[Foreign Exchange with Fareed Zakaria]]'' on [[PBS]] (2005–08). His weekly show, ''[[Fareed Zakaria GPS]]'' (''Global Public Square''), premiered on [[CNN]] in June 2008. It airs twice weekly in the United States and four times weekly on CNN International, reaching over 200 million homes. It celebrated its 10th anniversary on June 5, 2018, as announced on the weekly foreign affairs show on CNN. In 2013 he became one of the producers for the [[HBO]] series ''[[Vice (TV series)|Vice]]'', for which he serves as a consultant. Zakaria, a member of the [[Berggruen Institute]], additionally features as an interlocutor for the annual [[The Berggruen Prize|Berggruen Prize]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/style/2017/12/onora-oneill-berggruen-institute|title=Pondering Humanity, Technology, and Net Neutrality at the Berggruen Institute Gala|last=Binlot|first=Ann|date=|work=Vanity Fair|access-date=2017-12-17|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/nicolas-berggruen-philosophy-prize-333452|title=Nicolas Berggruen's $1 Million Philosophy Prize - artnet News|date=2015-09-17|work=artnet News|access-date=2017-12-17|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://montreal.ctvnews.ca/charles-taylor-accepts-million-dollar-prize-1.3187270|title=Charles Taylor accepts million-dollar prize|date=2016-12-02|work=Montreal|access-date=2017-12-17|language=en-CA}} ==Political views== Zakaria self-identifies as a "[[Centrism|centrist]]",{{cite news|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2005-08-09/news/the-interpreter/2|title=The Interpreter|work=[[The Village Voice]]|date=9 August 2005|author=Press, Joy}} though he has been described variously as a [[Modern liberalism in the United States|political liberal]],[https://www.forbes.com/2009/01/22/influential-media-obama-oped-cx_tv_ee_hra_0122liberal_slide_16.html?thisSpeed=15000 In Depth: The 25 Most Influential Liberals In The U.S. Media]. ''[[Forbes]]''. Published 22 January 2009. a [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]],{{cite magazine |last=Maneker |first=Marion |date=21 April 2003 |title=Man of the World |url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/news/politics/national/features/n_8621/ |magazine=New York |access-date=16 July 2017}} a moderate,[http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/News/News_By_Industry/ET_Cetera/Fareed_Zakaria_as_US_secretary_of_state/articleshow/3682292.cms Fareed Zakaria as US secretary of state?] ''The Economic Times''. Published 6 November 2008. {{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} or a [[Radical center (politics)|radical centrist]].Olson, Robert (January–February 2005). "[http://www.wfs.org/revsatinjf05.htm The Rise of 'Radical Middle' Politics] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120716184225/http://www.wfs.org/revsatinjf05.htm |date=16 July 2012 }}". ''The Futurist'', vol. 39, no. 1, pp. 45–47. Publication of the [[World Future Society]]. Retrieved 26 February 2013. [[George Stephanopoulos]] said of him in 2003, "He's so well versed in politics, and he can't be pigeonholed. I can't be sure whenever I turn to him where he's going to be coming from or what he's going to say." Zakaria wrote in February 2008 that "Conservatism grew powerful in the 1970s and 1980s because it proposed solutions appropriate to the problems of the age", adding that "a new world requires new thinking".[http://www.newsweek.com/id/112770 The End of Conservatism]. He supported Barack Obama during the 2008 Democratic primary campaign and also for president. In January 2009 ''[[Forbes]]'' referred to Zakaria as one of the 25 most influential liberals in the [[American media]]. Zakaria has stated that he tries not to be devoted to any type of ideology, saying "I feel that's part of my job... which is not to pick sides but to explain what I think is happening on the ground. I can't say, 'This is my team and I'm going to root for them no matter what they do.'" [[File:Christopher Murray, Jens Stoltenberg, Bill Gates, Gordon Brown, Olusegun Obasanjo, Fareed Zakaria, Giulio Tremonti - World Economic Forum Annual Meeting Davos 2006.jpg|right|thumb|Fareed Zakaria at [[World Economic Forum]] 2006, [[Davos]], [[Switzerland]] (second from the right)]] As a student at [[Yale University]] in the mid 1980s, Zakaria opposed anti-apartheid divestment and argued that Yale should not divest from its holdings in [[South Africa]].https://pbs.twimg.com/media/DBAQuxbXYAAkEus.jpg Zakaria "may have more intellectual range and insights than any other public thinker in the West," wrote David Shribman in ''[[The Boston Globe]]''.{{cite news |last=Shribman |first=David M. |title=Globalization, its discontents, and its upside |url=http://archive.boston.com/ae/books/articles/2008/06/01/globalization_its_discontents_and_its_upside/ |work=The Boston Globe |date=1 June 2008 |access-date=16 July 2017}} In 2003, former Secretary of State [[Henry Kissinger]] told ''[[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]]'' that Zakaria “has a first-class mind and likes to say things that run against conventional wisdom.” However, in 2011, the editors of ''[[The New Republic]]'' included him in a list of "over-rated thinkers" and commented, "There's something suspicious about a thinker always so perfectly in tune with the moment."{{cite news |author= |title=Over-Rated Thinkers |url=https://newrepublic.com/article/96141/over-rated-thinkers |work=The New Republic |date=3 November 2011 |access-date=16 July 2017}} Zakaria's books include ''[[The Future of Freedom]]'' and ''[[The Post-American World]]''. ''The Future of Freedom'' argues that what is defined as democracy in the Western world is actually "[[liberal democracy]]", a combination of [[constitutional liberalism]] and participatory politics. Zakaria points out that protection of liberty and the rule of law actually preceded popular elections by centuries in Western Europe, and that when countries only adopt elections without the protection of liberty, they create "illiberal democracy". ''The Post-American World'', published in 2008 before the financial crisis, argued that the most important trend of modern times is the "rise of the rest," the economic emergence of China, India, Brazil, and other countries.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/05/15/AR2008051504202.html|title=The Rise of Non-Americanism|last=Khanna|first=Parag|date=18 May 2008|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=13 May 2012}} From 2006, Zakaria has also criticized what he views as "fear-based" American policies employed not only in combating terrorism, but also in enforcing immigration and drug smuggling laws, and has argued in favor of decriminalization of drugs and citizenship for presently illegal immigrants to the United States of all backgrounds.Intelligence 2 Ltd., ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20110720062937/http://www.intelligencesquared.com/events/america-is-to-blame-for-mexicos-drug-war America is to blame for Mexico's drug war]'', 1 December 2009, retrieved 24 April 2011{{cite news |last=Zakaria |first=Fareed |date=3 May 2008 |title=Excerpt: Zakaria’s ‘The Post-American World’ |url=http://www.newsweek.com/excerpt-zakarias-post-american-world-89645 |work=Newsweek |access-date=16 July 2017}}''[http://www.cc.com/video-clips/4h35c9/the-daily-show-with-jon-stewart-fareed-zakaria-pt--1 Interview with Fareed Zakaria, Part 1]'', [[The Daily Show]] with Jon Stewart, 28 March 2006: "We are not going to deport them (illegal immigrants)—no democracy would..."Most of these [illegal immigrants], almost all of them, couldn't do anything...that would break the law. The minute they do that, they would be deported." Referring to his views on [[Iran]], [[Leon Wieseltier]] described Zakaria as a "consummate spokesman for the [[shibboleths]] of the [[White House]] and for the smooth new worldliness, the at-the-highest-levels impatience with democracy and human rights as central objectives of our foreign policy, that now characterize advanced liberal thinking about America's role in the world."{{cite news |last=Wieseltier |first=Leon |date=25 June 2010 |title=The realism of seeking democracy in Iran |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/06/24/AR2010062404875.html |work=The Washington Post |access-date=16 July 2017}} Before the 2008 U.S. presidential election, Zakaria [[List of Barack Obama presidential campaign endorsements, 2008|endorsed]] [[Barack Obama]] on his CNN program.{{cite news|last=Zakaria|first=Fareed|title=FAREED ZAKARIA GPS|url=http://edition.cnn.tv/TRANSCRIPTS/0810/19/fzgps.01.html|accessdate=22 May 2011|publisher=CNN|date=19 October 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815114853/http://edition.cnn.tv/TRANSCRIPTS/0810/19/fzgps.01.html|archivedate=15 August 2011|df=dmy-all}} In May 2011 ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that President Obama has "sounded out prominent journalists like Fareed Zakaria ... and [[Thomas Friedman|Thomas L. Friedman]]" concerning Middle East issues.{{cite news|last=Landler|first=Mark|title=Obama Seeks Reset in Arab World|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/12/us/politics/12prexy.html?_r=1&sq=zakaria&st=nyt&scp=1&pagewanted=print|accessdate=22 May 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=11 May 2011}} [[File:Plenary session of St Petersburg International Economic Forum (2016-06-17) 07.jpg|thumb|Fareed Zakaria and [[Vladimir Putin]] at [[St. Petersburg International Economic Forum]], 17 June 2016]] After the 9/11 attacks, in a ''Newsweek ''cover essay, "Why They Hate Us," Zakaria argued that Islamic extremism was not fundamentally rooted in Islam, nor could it be claimed a reaction to American foreign policy. He located the problem in the political-social-economic stagnation of Arab societies, which then bred an extreme, religious opposition. He portrayed Osama bin Laden as one in a long line of extremists who used religion to justify mass murder. Zakaria argued for an intergenerational effort to create more open and dynamic societies in Arab countries, and thereby helping Islam enter the modern world.{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2001/10/14/the-politics-of-rage-why-do-they-hate-us.html|title=The Politics of Rage: Why Do They Hate Us?|last=Zakaria|first=Fareed|date=2001-10-14|work=Newsweek|accessdate=25 February 2012}} Zakaria initially supported the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]]. He said at the time, "The place is so dysfunctional ... any stirring of the pot is good. America's involvement in the region is for the good." He argued for a United Nations–sanctioned operation with a much larger force—approximately 400,000 troops—than was actually employed by the administration of President [[George W. Bush]]. However, he soon became a critic. In addition to objecting to the war plan, he frequently criticized the way the Bush administration was running the [[History of Iraq (2003–2011)|occupation of Iraq]]. He argued against the disbanding of the army and bureaucracy yet supported the [[de-Baathification]] programs.{{cite web|author=Fareed Zakaria |url=http://www.newsweek.com/giving-peace-real-chance-137835|title=Giving Peace a Real Chance |publisher=Newsweek |date=1 June 2003 |accessdate=10 Nov 2014}} He continued to argue that a functioning democracy in Iraq would be a powerful new model for Arab politics but suggested that an honest accounting would have to say that the costs of the invasion had been much higher than the benefits. He opposed the Iraq [[Iraq War troop surge of 2007|surge]] in March 2007, writing that it would work militarily but not politically, still leaving Iraq divided among its three communities. Instead he advocated that Washington push hard for a political settlement between the Sunni Arabs, Shia Arabs, and Kurds, and begin a reduction in forces to only 60,000 troops.{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2007/03/04/the-surge-that-might-work.html|title=The Surge That Might Work|last=Zakaria|first=Fareed|date=3 April 2007|work=Newsweek|accessdate=25 February 2012}} He later wrote that the surge "succeeded" militarily but that it did not produce a political compact and that Iraq remains divided along sectarian lines, undermining its unity, democracy, and legacy.{{cite news| url=http://newsweek.washingtonpost.com/postglobal/fareed_zakaria/2008/11/mccains_downfall_republican_fo.html?hpid=opinionsbox1 | work=The Washington Post | title=McCain's Downfall: Republican Foreign Policy | accessdate=2010-05-03}}{{cite news|author=Fareed Zakaria|url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/200858 |title=Zakaria: How to End in Iraq |publisher=Newsweek |date=6 June 2009 |accessdate=2010-10-01}} Zakaria supported the April 2017 [[2017 Shayrat missile strike|U.S. missile strike]] against a Syrian government–controlled airbase. Zakaria praised [[President Trump]]'s strike and said it was the moment "[he] became president of the United States.”{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/apr/7/fareed-zakaria-donald-trump-became-president-last-/| work=The Washington Times | title=CNN’s Fareed Zakaria: ‘Donald Trump became president’ last night | accessdate=2017-05-02}} ==Honors and awards== Zakaria has been nominated five times for the [[National Magazine Award]], and won it once, for his columns and commentary. His show has won a [[Peabody Award]][http://www.peabodyawards.com/award-profile/restoring-the-american-dream-fixing-education-and-cnns-fareed-zakaria-gps-i 71st Annual Peabody Awards], May 2012 and been nominated for several Emmys. He was conferred ''[[India Abroad]]'' Person of the Year 2008 award on 20 March 2009, in New York.{{cite web|url=http://specials.rediff.com/news/2009/mar/21slide1-fareed-zakaria-is-the-india-abroad-person-of-the-year.htm |title=rediff.com: Fareed Zakaria is India Abroad Person of the Year |publisher=Specials.rediff.com |date=21 March 2009 |accessdate=2010-10-01}} Filmmaker [[Mira Nair]], who won the award for year 2007, honored her successor. He has received honorary degrees from [[Harvard University]], [[Brown University]], [[Duke University]], [[Johns Hopkins University]], the [[University of Miami]], [[Oberlin College]], [[Bates College]], and the [[University of Oklahoma]] among others.{{cite news |url=http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2012/05/eight-receive-honorary-degrees/|title=Eight receive honorary degrees|last=Koch|first=Katie|author2=Corydon Ireland |author3=Alvin Powell |author4=Colleen Walsh |date=24 May 2012 |work=[[Harvard Gazette]] |access-date=26 May 2012}} He was the 2000 Annual Orator of the [[Philomathean Society]] of the [[University of Pennsylvania]]. In January 2010, Zakaria was given the [[Padma Bhushan]] award by the Indian government for his contribution to the field of journalism.{{cite web|author= |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/list-of-padma-awardees/109180-3.html |title=List of Padma awardees |publisher=[[IBNLive]] |date=3 February 2010 |accessdate=2010-10-01}} He serves on the board of the Council on Foreign Relations, the New America Foundation, Columbia University's International House, City College of New York's Colin Powell School for Civic and Global Leadership, and Shakespeare and Company.{{cn|date=August 2017}} He was a trustee of [[Yale Corporation]], the governing body of Yale University{{cite web|title=Journalist Fareed Zakaria resigns from Yale Corporation|url=http://www.nhregister.com/news/article/Journalist-Fareed-Zakaria-resigns-from-Yale-11512578.php|work=[[New Haven Register]] |last=DeMatteo|first= Ann |date=August 20, 2012|accessdate=August 23, 2017}} and the Trilateral Commission.{{cn|date=August 2017}} ==Controversies== ===Role in the 2003 invasion of Iraq=== In his 2006 book ''[[State of Denial]]'', journalist [[Bob Woodward]] of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' described a 29 November 2001, meeting of Middle East analysts, including Zakaria, that was convened at the request of the then Deputy Secretary of Defense [[Paul D. Wolfowitz|Paul Wolfowitz]]. According to a story in ''[[The New York Times]]'' on Woodward's book, the Wolfowitz meeting ultimately produced a report for [[President of the United States|President]] [[George W. Bush]] that supported the subsequent [[2003 invasion of Iraq|invasion of Iraq]]. Zakaria, however, later told ''The New York Times'' that he had briefly attended what he thought was "a brainstorming session".{{cite news|last=Bosman|first=Julie|title=Secret Iraq Meeting Included Journalists|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=9 October 2006|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/09/business/media/09zakaria.html?ex=1318046400&en=ab43603ab31201e7&ei=5090&partner=rssuserland&emc=rss|accessdate=2007-01-16}} He was not told that a report would be prepared for the President, and in fact, the report did not have his name on it. The ''Times'' issued a correction.Quote: "An article in Business Day on Oct. 9 about journalists who attended a secret meeting in November 2001 called by Paul D. Wolfowitz, then the deputy secretary of defense, referred incorrectly to the participation of Fareed Zakaria, the editor of ''Newsweek International'' and a ''Newsweek'' columnist. Mr. Zakaria was not told that the meeting would produce a report for the Bush administration, nor did his name appear on the report." ===Debate on the Park51 Islamic Center=== In 2010, in protest at the [[Anti-Defamation League]]'s opposition to the building of the [[Park51]] mosque and Islamic cultural center two blocks from the [[World Trade Center site]], Zakaria returned the Hubert H. Humphrey First Amendment Freedoms Prize awarded to him by the ADL in 2005. He declared that the ADL's opposition to the mosque meant that he could not "in good conscience keep [the award] anymore". In support of his decision, he stated that the larger issue in the controversy is freedom of religion in America, even while acknowledging that he is not a religious person. He also wrote that a "moderate, mainstream version of Islam" is essential to winning the war on terror, and that moves like the ADL's make it harder for such a moderate version of Islam to emerge and thrive.{{Cite news | title = Build the Ground Zero Mosque | first = Fareed | last = Zakaria | work = Newsweek | date = 6 August 2010 | url = http://www.newsweek.com/2010/08/06/the-real-ground-zero.html | accessdate = 7 August 2010 }}{{Cite news | title = Fareed Zakaria's Letter to the ADL | first = Fareed | last = Zakaria | work = Newsweek | date = 6 August 2010 | url = http://www.newsweek.com/2010/08/06/fareed-zakaria-s-letter-to-the-adl.html | accessdate = 7 August 2010 }}{{Cite news |title = Fareed Zakaria returns ADL award in protest |work = The Spy Report |publisher = Media Spy |date = 7 August 2010 |url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2010/08/07/us-fareed-zakaria-returns-adl-award-in-protest/ |accessdate = 7 August 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130113000125/http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2010/08/07/us-fareed-zakaria-returns-adl-award-in-protest/ |archivedate = 13 January 2013 |df = dmy-all }} On 8 August 2010, edition of ''[[Fareed Zakaria GPS]]'', Zakaria addressed the issue, stating that in returning his award, he had hoped that the ADL would reconsider their stance.{{Cite news | title = Fareed: Don't demonize Islamic centre | work = CNN | date = 8 August 2010 | url = http://www.cnn.com/video/#/video/bestoftv/2010/08/06/gps.fareed.take.cnn/ | accessdate = 9 August 2010 }} ===Plagiarism allegations=== [[File:Fareed Zakaria World Economic Forum 2013.jpg|thumb|Fareed Zakaria in 2013]] Zakaria was suspended for a week in August 2012 while ''Time'' and CNN investigated an allegation of plagiarism{{cite news|last=Amira|first=Dan|title=Fareed Zakaria sure looks like he stole from The New Yorker|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2012/08/fareed-zakaria-plagiarism-time-new-yorker.html|newspaper=New York|date=10 August 2012}} involving an August 20 column on gun control with similarities to a ''New Yorker'' article by [[Jill Lepore]]. In a statement Zakaria apologized, saying that he had made "a terrible mistake."{{cite news|url=http://globalpublicsquare.blogs.cnn.com/2012/08/10/a-statement-from-fareed/ |title=Statement from Fareed |date=10 August 2012 |access-date=2012-08-18 |work=CNN}}{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/ondeadline/post/2012/08/time-cnn-suspend-fareed-zakaria-for-plagiarism/1#.UC-3293ib8k |title=Time, CNN suspend Fareed Zakaria for plagiarism |date=8 October 2012 |accessdate=2012-08-18 |work=USA Today}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/20/business/media/scandal-threatens-fareed-zakarias-image-as-media-star.html |title=A Media Personality, Suffering a Blow to His Image, Ponders a Lesson |work=The New York Times |date=19 August 2012 |access-date=2012-08-19 |first=Christine |last=Haughney}} Six days later, after a review of his research notes and years of prior commentary, ''Time'' and CNN reinstated Zakaria. ''Time'' described the incident as "isolated" and "unintentional"; and CNN "... found nothing that merited continuing the suspension...."{{cite news |last=Haughney |first=Christine |date=16 August 2012 |title=Time and CNN Reinstate Journalist After Review |url=https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/08/16/after-review-time-says-fareed-zakarias-plagiarism-was-isolated-incident/ |newspaper=The New York Times}}{{cite news|last=Byers|first=Dylan|title=Fareed Zakaria to stay at Time, CNN|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/media/2012/08/fareed-zakaria-to-stay-at-time-magazine-132350.html|newspaper=Politico|date=16 August 2012}}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/fareed-zakaria-reinstated-at-cnn-time-after-suspension/2012/08/16/50ba9844-e80b-11e1-a3d2-2a05679928ef_story.html |title=Fareed Zakaria reinstated at CNN and Time |date=16 August 2012 |access-date=2012-08-18 |work=The Washington Post |first=Carolyn |last=Hax}} The controversy was reignited in September 2014, when ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'' and ''[[The Week]]'' magazines reported on allegations made in [[pseudonym]]ous blogs.{{cite news|title=CNN Does Not Get to Cherrypick the Rules of Journalism|url=http://www.esquire.com/blogs/news/cnn-rules-of-journalism|newspaper=Esquire|date=22 September 2014}}{{cite news|last=Cooper|first=Ryan|title=Why does Fareed Zakaria still have a job?|url=https://theweek.com/article/index/268453/why-does-fareed-zakaria-still-have-a-job|newspaper=The Week|date=22 September 2014}}{{cite news|title=Fareed Zakaria's statement responding to the charges by two anonymous bloggers|url=http://fareedzakaria.com/2014/08/19/fareed-zakarias-statement-responding-to-the-charges-by-two-anonymous-bloggers/|date=19 August 2014|access-date=20 August 2014|publisher=Fareed Zakaria.com}} ''Newsweek'' initially added a blanket warning to its archive of articles penned by Zakaria, but after an investigation of his several hundred columns for the magazine, found improper citation in only seven.{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/media/2014/09/newsweek-adds-plagiarism-warning-to-fareed-zakaria-196287.html|title=Newsweek adds plagiarism warning to Fareed Zakaria articles|publisher=Politico|date=29 September 2014|author=Dylan Byers}}{{cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/interview-anonymous-media-watchdogs-who-accused-fareed-zakaria-plagiarism-282839|title=An Interview With the Anonymous Media Watchdogs Who Accused Fareed Zakaria of Plagiarism|work=Newsweek|date=7 November 2014|author=Taylor Wofford and Zach Schonfeld}} Similarly, after allegations surfaced on Twitter regarding the originality of one of Zakaria's columns for ''Slate'', the online magazine appended a notice to the article indicating that, "This piece does not meet Slate’s editorial standards, having failed to properly attribute quotations and information...".{{cite news|title=Editor’s note|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/wines_world/1998/02/toward_the_wet_martini.html|newspaper=Slate|date=10 November 2014}} However, ''Slate'' Editor-in-Chief [[Jacob Weisberg]], who had, months before, exchanged barbs with one of the aforementioned anonymous bloggers on [[Twitter]] in defense of Zakaria,{{cite web |url=http://gawker.com/newsweek-warns-readers-about-fareed-zakaria-s-plagiaris-1640433014 |title=Newsweek Warns Readers About Fareed Zakaria’s Plagiarism |date=29 September 2014 |website=Gawker |deadurl=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141101041101/http://gawker.com/newsweek-warns-readers-about-fareed-zakaria-s-plagiaris-1640433014 |archive-date=1 November 2014 |df=dmy }} maintained his original position that what Zakaria did was not plagiarism.{{cite news |last=Grove |first=Lloyd |date=12 November 2014 |title=Can Fareed Zakaria Survive A Plagiarism Firestorm? |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/can-fareed-zakaria-survive-a-plagiarism-firestorm |website=The Daily Beast |access-date=13 November 2014}} Corrections to selected Zakaria columns were also issued by ''The Washington Post'', which had responded to the initial allegations by telling the ''[[Poynter Institute|Poynter]]'' media industry news site that it would investigate.{{cite news|title=6 of Zakaria’s Washington Post pieces have originality issues, critics say|url=http://www.poynter.org/mediawire/top-stories/280651/6-of-zakarias-washington-post-pieces-have-originality-issues-critics-say/|newspaper=Poynter.org|date=10 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141111044137/http://www.poynter.org/mediawire/top-stories/280651/6-of-zakarias-washington-post-pieces-have-originality-issues-critics-say/|archivedate=11 November 2014|df=dmy-all}} Later on the same day, November 10, the ''Post'' said that it had found "problematic" sourcing in five Zakaria columns, "and will likely note the lack of attribution in archived editions of the articles."{{cite news|title=Post finds problematic sourcing in some Zakaria columns|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/post-finds-problematic-sourcing-in-some-zakaria-columns/2014/11/10/32086280-692a-11e4-9fb4-a622dae742a2_story.html|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=10 November 2014}} However, editors at ''The Washington Post'' and ''Newsweek ''denied that Zakaria's errors constituted plagiarism. ==Personal life== Zakaria is a naturalized American citizen.{{cite news |last=Zakaria |first=Fareed |date=July 15, 2001 |title=America Doesn't Need Crusades |url=http://www.newsweek.com/america-doesnt-need-crusades-155181 |work=Newsweek |access-date=July 17, 2017}} He currently resides in [[New York City]]. Zakaria is a self-described secular and nonpracticing Muslim. He added: "My views on faith are complicated—somewhere between [[deism]] and [[agnosticism]]. I am completely secular in my outlook."{{cite news |last=Zakaria |first=Fareed |date=December 10, 2015 |title=I am a Muslim. But Trump’s views appall me because I am an American. |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/i-am-a-muslim-but-trumps-views-appall-me-because-i-am-an-american/2015/12/10/fcba9ea6-9f6d-11e5-8728-1af6af208198_story.html |work=The Washington Post |access-date=December 13, 2015}}{{cite news |last=Zakaria |first=Fareed |date=December 12, 2015 |title=Fareed's Take: Why Trump's rhetoric is dangerous |url=http://www.cnn.com/videos/tv/2015/12/12/exp-gps-1213-take-muslim.cnn |work=Fareed Zakaria GPS |publisher=CNN |access-date=December 13, 2015}} ==Bibliography== * ''In Defense of a Liberal Education'', Fareed Zakaria, (W.W. Norton & Company; 2015) {{ISBN|978-0-393-24768-8}} * ''The Post-American World, Release 2.0'', Fareed Zakaria, (W.W. Norton & Company; 2011) {{ISBN|0-393-08180-X}} * ''[[The Post-American World]]'', Fareed Zakaria, (W.W. Norton & Company; 2008) {{ISBN|0-393-06235-X}} * ''[[The Future of Freedom]]: Illiberal Democracy at Home and Abroad'', Fareed Zakaria, (W.W. Norton & Company; 2003) {{ISBN|0-393-04764-4}} * ''From Wealth to Power'', Fareed Zakaria, (Princeton University Press; 1998) {{ISBN|0-691-04496-1}} * ''The American Encounter: The United States and the Making of the Modern World Essays from 75 Years of Foreign Affairs'', edited by James F. Hoge and Fareed Zakaria, (Basic Books; 1997) {{ISBN|0-465-00170-X}} ==See also== * [[Indians in the New York City metropolitan region]] * [[List of Yale University people]] * [[List of Harvard University people]] * [[New Yorkers in journalism]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} {{wikiquote}} * [http://www.fareedzakaria.com/ FareedZakaria.com] Official site * {{Facebook|FareedZakaria}} * [http://www.cnn.com/shows/fareed-zakaria-gps Global Public Square (GPS)] at ''[[CNN]]'' *https://www.arcamax.com/politics/fromtheleft/fareedzakaria/ * [http://www.dailystar.com.lb/Fareed-Zakaria.ashx Column archive] at ''[[Daily Star (Lebanon)|The Daily Star]]'' * [http://www.newsweek.com/authors/fareed-zakaria.html Column archive (through 2010)] at ''[[Newsweek]]'' * {{IMDb name|1821472}} * {{Worldcat id|lccn-n97-47622}} * {{C-SPAN|Fareed Zakaria}} {{CNN Anchors}} {{The Washington Post Writers Group}} {{PadmaBhushanAwardRecipients 2010–19}} revision.text:
'''Flower Backhouse''' (died 17 July 1700) was an 18th-century English noblewoman, notable as [[First Lady of the Bedchamber]] to [[Anne, Queen of Great Britain|Queen Anne]]. She was Countess of Clarendon from 1670 until her death.
[[File:The house at Swallowfield Park (geograph 4365319).jpg|thumb|Swallowfield Park House]] She was the daughter of the philosopher [[William Backhouse]]<ref>{{Cite DNB |first=Thompson |last=Cooper |wstitle=Backhouse, William |volume=2 |pages=320–321}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Berkshire History: Biographies: William Backhouse (1593-1662) |url= http://www.berkshirehistory.com/bios/wbackhouse.html |publisher=Nash Ford Publishing |year=2002 |accessdate=29 August 2007}}</ref> and his wife, the former Ann Richards. (Other sources say she was the daughter of Sir John Backhouse by his wife, the former Flower Henshaw.)<ref> George Edward Cokayne, editor, The Complete Baronetage, 5 volumes (no date (c. 1900); reprint, Gloucester, U.K.: Alan Sutton Publishing, 1983), volume III, page 128.</ref>
She was married three times, her first marriage being to William Bishop of [[South Warnborough]], sometime prior to 1662. Following Bishop's death, she married secondly her father's cousin, [[Backhouse baronets|Sir William Backhouse, Bart.]],<ref>{{cite DNB|wstitle=Backhouse, William}}</ref> at [[St Andrew Holborn (church)|St Andrew Holborn]] on 23 November 1662; Backhouse died in 1669. From her second husband she inherited nine shares in the [[New River Company]].<ref name="Bio Brit">{{cite book|title=Biographia Britannica: Or, The Lives of the Most Eminent Persons ... |year=1757 |volume=4 |publisher=W. Innys |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=Y4lDAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA2267 2267]}}</ref>
She married her third husband, [[Henry Hyde, 2nd Earl of Clarendon|Henry Hyde, Lord Cornbury]], on 19 October 1670,<ref>Peter W. Hammond, editor, The Complete Peerage or a History of the House of Lords and All its Members From the Earliest Times, Volume XIV: Addenda & Corrigenda (Stroud, Gloucestershire, U.K.: Sutton Publishing, 1998), page 185. </ref> as his second wife. This gained Clarendon the manor and house of [[Swallowfield Park]], [[Berkshire]]. Hyde became Earl of Clarendon in 1676.<ref name="Bio Brit"/>
Clarendon was brother to Queen Anne's mother [[Anne Hyde]] and sometime after her third marriage Backhouse became Anne's [[First Lady of the Bedchamber]]. However, Backhouse was hated by Anne's best friend [[Sarah Churchill, Duchess of Marlborough|Sarah Churchill]], who called her "the madwoman" and may have brought about Anne's later dislike of Backhouse.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Backhouse, Flower}} [[Category:1700 deaths]] [[Category:First Ladies of the Bedchamber]] [[Category:English countesses|Clarendon]] [[Category:Wives of baronets]] [[Category:17th-century English women]] [[Category:Women of the Stuart period]]

page.title: Four Lords of the Warring States

revision.text:
{{Chinese|t=戰國四公子|s=战国四公子|p=Zhànguó sì gōngzǐ|l="The Four Young LordsGōngzǐ (公子) literally means "the lord's son", "the young lord" or "the lordling", indicating the name bearer being a son of a ruler of a client state. of the Warring States"}} The '''Four Lords of the Warring States''' were four powerful aristocrats of the late [[Warring States period]] of [[History of China|Chinese history]] who exerted a strong influence on the politics of their respective states in the third century BCE.[http://san.beck.org/EC13-Chou.html#9 Period of the Warring States] During this time, the [[Zhou dynasty|Zhou]] king was a mere figurehead, and [[Seven Warring States|seven states]] led by aristocratic families competed for real power. Although they were not themselves monarchs, four aristocrats stood out because of their tremendous military power and wealth: [[Lord Mengchang]] (d. 279{{nbsp}}{{sc|BCE}}) of [[Qi (state)|Qi]], [[Lord Pingyuan]] (d. 251{{nbsp}}{{sc|BCE}}) of [[Zhao (state)|Zhao]], [[Lord Xinling]] (d. 243{{nbsp}}{{sc|BCE}}) of [[Wei (state)|Wei]] and [[Lord Chunshen]] (d. 238{{nbsp}}{{sc|BCE}}) of [[Chu (state)|Chu]].{{sfn|Lewis|1999|p=639 ("these men dominated the governments of their states, accumulated large fortunes, assembled armies of personal followers, and rivaled the monarch's authority")}} All four were renowned for their activity in the politics of their era as well as being the persona of their state respectively at the time; they also wielded influence via the cultivation and housing of many talented house-guests, who often included learned men and tacticians. As such, they came to be the most prominent patrons of the ''shi'' ({{lang|zh-hans|士}}) or scholar-knights, stimulating the intellectual life of the time. Their prestige became the inspiration for [[Lü Buwei]] when he created [[Lüshi Chunqiu|his academic analogue]] in [[Qin (state)|Qin]]. == References in the Records of the Grand Historian == These four lords are paralleled in some books of ''the [[Records of the Grand Historian]]'', the first of the [[Twenty-Four Histories]] of China. In ''the Biographies of Lord Pingyuan and Yu Qing,''[http://ctext.org/shiji/ping-yuan-jun-yu-qing-lie-zhuan Biographies of Lord Pingyuan and Yu Qing] 是時齊有孟嘗，魏有信陵，楚有春申，故爭相傾以待士。
At this time, [in addition to Lord Pingyuan in Zhao,] in Qi lived Mengchang, in Wei Xinling, and in Chu Chunshen. They competed to invite ''shi'' (talents).
In ''the Biography of Lord Chunshen,''[http://ctext.org/shiji/chun-shen-jun-lie-zhuan Biography of Lord Chunshen] 春申君既相楚，是時齊有孟嘗君，趙有平原君，魏有信陵君，方爭下士，招致賓客，以相傾奪，輔國持權。
Lord Chunshen now stood as the prime minister of the Kingdom of Chu. At this time, in Qi lived Lord Mengchang, in Zhao Lord Pingyuan, and in Wei Lord Xinling. They competed to humble themselves before ''shi'' (talents) [to hire them], invited brilliant guests, and tried to defeat each other. They sustained their states and held the real power.
== Lord Mengchang == {{main|Lord Mengchang}} [[Lord Mengchang]] was an aristocrat of the [[State of Qi]]. He was born Tian Wen, son of Tian Ying and the grandson of King Wei of Qi. He succeeded his father's fief in [[Xue]]. == Lord Pingyuan == {{main|Lord Pingyuan}} Born Zhao Sheng, he was a son of [[King Wuling of Zhao]], brother of [[King Huiwen of Zhao|King Huiwen]] and uncle to [[King Xiaocheng of Zhao|King Xiaocheng]]. During his life, he was thrice appointed the Prime Minister of the [[State of Zhao]]. Zhao Sheng's fief was the City of Dongwu. Lord Pingyuan was his title, and some of his famous retainers included the philosophers [[Xun Kuang]] and [[Gongsun Long]], the [[Yin and Yang]] master [[Zou Yan]], and the diplomat [[Mao Sui]]. == Lord Xinling == {{main|Lord Xinling}} Born as Wei Wuji, he was the son of King Zhao of the [[State of Wei]] and younger half-brother to [[King Anxi of Wei]]. In 277{{nbsp}}{{sc|BCE}}, King Anxi assigned Wei Wuji the fief of Xinling. At the height of his career, he was the supreme commander of the armed forces of the [[State of Wei|Kingdom of Wei]]. After stepping down, Lord Xinling became dispirited and died in 243{{nbsp}}{{sc|BCE}}. == Lord Chunshen == {{main|Lord Chunshen}} Born Huang Xie, he was originally a government official working for [[King Qingxiang of Chu]], and later followed Crown Prince Wan when he spent ten years as a hostage in the [[State of Qin|Kingdom of Qin]]. After the death of King Qingxiang, Prince Wan and Huang Xie returned to the [[State of Chu|Kingdom of Chu]]. Prince Wan was enthroned as [[King Kaolie of Chu]], while Huang Xie was appointed Prime Minister and received the title of Lord Chunshen. For the next 25 years, Lord Chunshen remained Prime Minister of Chu, until his assassination by Li Yuan in 238{{nbsp}}{{sc|BCE}}. == See also == *[[Five Hegemons]] == References == ===Notes=== {{reflist}} ===Works cited=== *{{citation|last=Lewis|first=Mark Edward|year=1999|chapter=Warring States Political History|pages=587–650|title=The Cambridge History of Ancient China: From the Origins of Civilization to 222 B.C.|editors=Michael Loewe and Edward L. Shaughnessy (eds.)|location=Cambridge|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=0-521-47030-7}}. {{Four Lords of the Warring States}} [[Category:Lists of Chinese people]] [[Category:Zhou dynasty nobility]] [[Category:Articles about multiple people in pre-Tang China]]

revision.text:
[[File:Herman Finkers3.jpg|thumb|Herman Finkers]] '''Hermenegildus Felix Victor Maria "Herman" Finkers''' [ɦɛrmeːnə'ɣɪɫdəs 'feːlɪks 'vɪktɔr ma'riaː "'ɦɛrmɑn" 'fɪŋkərs] (born December 9, 1954 in [[Almelo]], [[Overijssel]]) is a Dutch [[comedian]], who is well known in the Netherlands for his friendly, dry-witted humour and his ambiguous style of storytelling. In his way of telling a story the moral should never be in the way of a good joke or pun. His humour is never at the expense of others, except his brother [[Wilfried Finkers]], who is frequently the target of jokes. Wilfried Finkers co-wrote material and occasionally appeared in his brother's shows. Herman Finkers temporarily stopped performing in 2000, and soon afterwards he was diagnosed with [[B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia|a form of leukaemia]]. He was given an estimate of 10 to 15 years of life left. On August 5, 2006 a [[Fuchsia]] was named after him. In 2007 he started playing in theatres again, with a new show called "Na de Pauze" (After the Break). On 31 December 2015 he gave the traditional New Year's Eve performance ("Oudejaarsconference") on Dutch television, in which he remarked that the chance that he would become 90 years old was statistically larger than the chance that he died three years ago.
Finkers is a [[Catholic]].{{cn|date=March 2018}}
==Tweants== Finkers has a strong love for the [[Tweants dialect]]. He has translated a number of his shows into Tweants [[Dutch Low Saxon|Low Saxon]], which is his mother tongue. He also wrote and directed two short animation films, which were completely in Tweants: ''Kroamschudd'n in [[Mariaparochie]]'' (''[[Baby shower]] in Mary's Parish'', which tells the story of the birth of [[Christ]] in a setting of [[Twente]]) and his comic interpretation of [[William Shakespeare|William Shakespeare's]] ''[[Macbeth]]'', the former of which is shown annually around [[Christmas]] on regional television. After his retirement from theatre, Finkers played a role in the first [[Soap opera|soap series]] in Tweants: "Van Jonge Leu en Oale Groond" (Of Young People and Old Ground). For his efforts to promote the Tweants [[dialect]] he received the [[Johanna van Buuren]] prize.
== Theater performances == *Op Zwart Zangzaad ("On Black Birdseed") (1979) *De terugkeer van Joop Huizinga ("Joop Huizinga's Return") (1982) *De Diana Ros Show ("The Diana Ros Show") (1983) *EHBO is mijn lust en mijn leven ("First aid is the love of my life") (1985) *Het Meisje van de Slijterij ("The liquor store girl") (1987) *De zon gaat zinloos onder, morgen moet zij toch weer op ("The sun sets pointlessly, it has got to rise again tomorrow anyway") (1990) *Dat heeft zo'n jongen toch niet nodig ("A guy like him doesn't need that") (1992) *Geen spatader veranderd ("Not changed one bit", actually an untranslatable pun) (1995) (also in Tweants: "Gen spatoader aans") *Kalm aan en rap een beetje ("Take it easy, on the double") (1998) (also in Tweants: "Heanig an en rap wat") *Na de pauze ("After the break") (2007) *Oudejaarsconference 2015: Een uur Herman Finkers ("New Year's Eve Performance 2015: An hour of Herman Finkers") (2015)
== Discography == *Van zijn LP ("From his album") *EHBO is mijn lust en mijn leven ("First aid is the love of my life") *De zon gaat zinloos onder, morgen moet zij toch weer op (The sun sets pointlessly, she's got to get up tomorrow anyway.) *Carnaval der Dieren / Sint Joris Mis (Animal Carnival / Saint George Mass) *Kroamschudd'n in [[Mariaparochie]] / Macbeth (animation films) ("Baby shower" in Mary's Parish / Macbeth) *Dat heeft zo'n jongen toch niet nodig (A boy like that doesn't need that) *Geen spatader veranderd (Not changed one bit) *Kalm aan en rap een beetje. (Take it easy, on the double.) *Een engelhart in Rome (An angel's heart in Rome) (A thoughtful Finkers on audience in the [[Holy See|Vatican]])
== DVDs == Most of his theatre shows were released on VHS and DVD, and several years ago a box set of all these DVDs was made available.
== External links == * [http://www.hermanfinkers.nl/ Official web site]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Finkers, Herman}} [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Dutch comedians]] [[Category:Dutch cabaret performers]] [[Category:Dutch Roman Catholics]] [[Category:People from Almelo]] [[Category:People with cancer]]

'''Hugh Feeney''' (born 1951) was a [[volunteer (Irish republican)|volunteer]] of the [[Provisional Irish Republican Army]] who, together with [[Dolours Price]] and [[Marian Price]], organised the [[car bomb]]ings of the [[Old Bailey]] and [[Scotland Yard]] on March 8, 1973. He and ten members of his 11-man [[Active Service Unit|active service unit]] (ASU) were apprehended attempting to board a flight to Ireland shortly after the bombs were discovered.
==Arrest, conviction, and imprisonment== Feeney was convicted on 14 November 1973<ref name="BBCreport">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/november/14/newsid_4724000/4724181.stm|title=IRA gang convicted of London bombings|publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC)|work=On This Day|date=14 November 1973|accessdate=October 4, 2011}}</ref> and sentenced to [[life imprisonment]] for each of the four bombing charges against him, which were to run concurrently.
The other members of his group were sentenced to life imprisonment as well as an additional twenty years. Feeney and other members of the group were incarcerated in [[Brixton Prison]], and participated in a 205-day [[hunger strike]]<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[The Plain Dealer]]|date=5 March 1995|last=O'Malley|first=Michael|title=Sinn Féin Builds Image as Force for Peace}}</ref> with the goal of being transferred closer to their homes in [[Ulster]].<ref name=8june74>{{cite journal|journal=[[New York Times]]|date=8 June 1974|page=7|title=Irish Call Off Fast in British Jails}}</ref> Feeney and the other hunger strikers were force-fed by British authorities for 167 days<ref name=10jun74>{{cite journal|journal=The Irish Times|date=10 June 2010|last=Joyce|first=Joe|title=Hostages teach IRA kidnappers all about racing}}</ref> of their strike.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[The Irish Times]]|date=16 May 2011|last=Moriarty|first=Gerry|title=Old Bailey bomber charged over dissident threats to police}}</ref>
In May 1974, Feeney was one of a group of four prisoners whose transfer out of Brixton was demanded anonymously in exchange for the return of $19.2 million in stolen art.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=New York Times|date=4 May 1974|title=Irish Prisoners' Transfer Demanded for Stolen Art|page=1}}</ref> On 4 June 1974, the IRA kidnapped [[John Hely-Hutchinson, 7th Earl of Donoughmore]] and his wife in an unsuccessful attempt to exchange them for the release of Feeney, the Prices, and [[Gerry Kelly]].<ref name=10jun74/> The prisoners ended their hunger strike on 7 June 1974.<ref name=8june74/> Feeney was transferred to [[Long Kesh]] prison soon after the hunger strike ended.<ref name="Moloney2010">{{cite book|last=Moloney|first=Ed|title=Voices from the Grave: Two Men's War in Ireland|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HTWepzmb8H4C&pg=PA199|accessdate=27 September 2011|date=1 June 2010|publisher=PublicAffairs|isbn=978-1-58648-932-8|page=199ff}}</ref>
During this period he and [[Brendan Hughes]] wrote IRA [[communiqué]]s and articles for ''[[Republican News]]'' under the pen name "Brownie", although most material published under this pseudonym was written by [[Gerry Adams]].<ref name="Moloney2003">{{cite book|last=Moloney|first=Ed|authorlink=Ed Moloney|title=A Secret History of the IRA|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5PNAtCeYpgYC&pg=PA170|accessdate=27 September 2011|date=November 2003|publisher=W. W. Norton & Company|isbn=978-0-393-32502-7|page=170}}</ref> After Adams's release, Feeney began writing under the pseudonym "Salon".<ref name="Moloney2010"/>
==Release and later deportation== Feeney was released from custody in 1986.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[The Times]]|date=2 August 1991|title=Three in IRA bomb raids lose jail plea - 1973 car bombing campaign|last=Tendler|first=Stuart}}</ref> On 20 May 1991, he was arrested in [[New York City]] and [[Deportation|deported]] the next day for having illegally entered the [[United States]].
Feeney was arrested in the offices of ''The Irish People'', an [[Irish republicanism|Irish republican]] newspaper published by [[Martin Galvin]] in New York City. The arrest was controversial because it involved a [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) agent posing as a journalism student in order to gain access to the paper's editorial offices,<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Editor & Publisher]]|date=31 August 1991|title=Pseudo journalist|last=Wolper|first=Allan|url=http://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?&id=GALE%7CA11258924&v=2.1&u=whit75390&it=r&p=AONE&sw=w}}{{registration}}</ref> which was a violation of FBI policy at the time.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Editor & Publisher|date=21 September 1991|title=FBI criticized for posing as journalism student: Catholic college, archdiocese are upset|last=Wolper|first=Allan|url=http://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?&id=GALE%7CA11350245&v=2.1&u=whit75390&it=r&p=AONE&sw=w}}{{registration}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|40em}}
==Further reading== * Clutterbuck, Richard. ''Kidnap and Ransom''. Boston: Faber & Faber, 1978.<!-- ISSN/ISBN needed --> {{PIRA}}
